Shriver Hall, tonight and tomorrow evening at 8:30, is the
scene of the Barnstormers'
winter production, the prize winning drama, Death of A Salesman, by Arthur Miller.
Called by Brooks Atkinson,
former drama critic for the New
York Times, "one of the finest
dramas in the whole range of
the American Theatre", Death
of a Salesman is the drama of
one man's attempt to maintain
and justify his personal dignity,
in the face of overwhelming
odds. Willy Loman, a traveling
salesman by profession, has
lived his life believing in the
materialistic standards of success set by our society, and has
taught his two sons, Biff and
Happy that "the man who succeeds is one who is well liked."
In high school, Biff was the
school hero, an all around athlete
with the world at his feet, and a
great future ahead of him. But
Biff never made it, and now, seventeen years, he is a bitter and
disillusioned young man, constantly at odds with the ideals
that his father imbued in him.
In Willy's standards of success: to be known and admired
by others and to make plenty of
money, Biff sees only emptiness
—a hideous pit into which everyone pursuing these ideas is swal-

lowed up, and where they are
forced to conform to false values.
In this way, Death of a Salesman is more than the story of
two men with conflicting ideals,
it is a sharp look at society in
general and the goals it has set
up in our modern world. But
the strength of the play lies in,
Miller's sharp, intense dialogue,
which overpowers the stage with
tension and feeling. This production of Death of a Salesman
should be a truly exciting
theatre experience.
Tickets for the production are
being distributed for advertising
purposes and are not required for
admission.

Dr. Wickwire
Lectures On
'Russia Today'
Dr. Chester L. Wickwire,
Executive Secretary of the Johns
Hopkins University Y.M.C.A. and
Lecturer in Religion at the University, spoke yesterday at 4
o'clock on "Religion in the Soviet
Union."
His talk, the fifth in a series
of lectures sponsored by the
Y.M.C.A., was called "The Soviet Union Today Series." Past
lecturers have been Owen Lattimore, Dr. Robert Slusser and
Dr. Missan Oren from The Johns
Hopkins University, and Professor James P. Scanlon from
Goucher College. Previous lectures so far have dealt with the
Soviets in the Cuban crisis, the
ideology of ;Enver in China and
the Soviet, contemporary Soviet
philosophy, and Soviet appeal for
the developing countries.
On a viist to the Soviet Union
this summer, Dr. Wickwire was
accused by Soviet officials of distributing anti-Soviet literature
and his papers were confiscated
by the authorities. In a Moscow
conference 14 days after the incident he was given an apology
and his literature returned.
The lecture series will be concluded January 10, 1963 with a
talk by Norman F. Henley, lecturer in Russian at the University, entitled "The Unpatriotic Dr. Zhivago."

on the evolutionary source of the
